snippet: When a journalist from a reputable publication was compelled to confess on television before going to trial, it came as a surprise to many.
abstract: China's arrest of Wang Xiaolu, who writes for respected business magazine Caijing, during its August crackdown on so-called rumor-mongers has raised fears about government's tightening control over journalism and future of the publication.

byline.contributor: Cao Li contributed research from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: When a journalist from a reputable publication was compelled to confess on television before going to trial, it came as a surprise to many.

headline.main: Caijing Journalist’s Shaming Signals China’s Growing Control Over News Media
headline.print_headline: Reporter’s Shaming Signals China’s Tightening Control

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
